description: 15th century, from Middle English [Term?], from Middle French fidélité, from Latin fidēlitās, from fidēlis (“faithful”), from fidēs (“faith, loyalty”) (English faith), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰidʰ-, zero-grade of *bʰeydʰ- (“to command, to persuade, to trust”) (English bide). Doublet of fealty.

examples: the fidelity of the civil servants

entries.meaning: Loyalty to one's spouse or partner, including abstention from cheating or extramarital affairs.
Accuracy, or exact correspondence to some given quality or fact.
The degree to which a system accurately reproduces an input.
examples: By placing them closer to the source, we can reduce the number of messages in the system and this in turn is likely to improve the fidelity of the system.
